author: By Nate Cohn
title: Republicans’ Electoral College Edge, Once Seen as Ironclad, Looks to Be Fading
description: A review of the evidence that Donald Trump’s advantage relative to the national popular vote has declined significantly.
content: Ever since Donald J. Trump’s stunning victory in 2016 — when he lost the popular vote by almost three million votes but still triumphed with over 300 electoral votes — many who follow politics have believed Republicans hold an intractable advantage in the Electoral College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Hints at Iran Link to His 2 Assassination Attempts, Despite the Available Evidence
description: Officials have disclosed no ties to Iran in the cases in Pennsylvania and Florida, as Donald Trump questioned the F.B.I.’s investigations and mused about military action.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday suggested that Iran might have been behind the two assassination attempts against him even as officials have said there is no evidence to link those plots to Iranian threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Colgan
title: When Electrification has Power Beyond Its Climate Benefits
description: Jamal Lewis and Aloja Airewele are part of a group focused on electrification. They are leading conversations at the Times’s Climate Forward Changemaker Lunch.
content: Jamal Lewis’s path to climate work started when he came close to losing his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Did Sean Combs Firebomb Kid Cudi’s Car? Charges Allude to a Reported Arson.
description: The government does not name the victim of a firebombing cited in its case against Mr. Combs, but the timing and facts line up with a reported 2012 attack on the rapper’s car.
content: In their efforts to show that Sean Combs was capable of the sort of violence that helped him control a criminal enterprise, federal prosecutors have pointed to his possession of multiple firearms, a video that depicts him assaulting his girlfriend and broad language in court papers describing multiple acts of intimidation and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Your Local Restaurant Is Doing Sketch Comedy
description: Once the realm of low-budget TV advertising, the restaurant commercial with owners and staff as actors has returned on TikTok.
content: “Do not look at her, she’s going to try to sell us pancakes,” the TikTok video begins ominously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Republicans Pick Up Unlikely Allies in Key House Races: Unions
description: Democrats still dominate with organized labor. But in must-win swing races, Republicans are peeling off some union support, and feeling the benefits.
content: The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters praised one Republican congressman on national television. A major transportation union rated another among its most loyal supporters in Congress. And an influential building trades group said a third would help begin “restoring the sense of unity” the country had lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Julian Barnes
title: Threats to Trump May Prompt Changes in Travel Plans and Event Types
description: Secret Service officials have advised altering routines and rethinking rally locations, after threats from Iran and two assassination attempts.
content: Donald Trump’s advisers are considering whether to modify his travel after threats to his life from Iran and two assassination attempts, according to several people briefed on the matter, a shift that could affect the way the Republican nominee campaigns in the race’s final stretch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Donald Trump Embraces ‘Love’
description: Politicians often lean toward hyperbole, but the frequent use of the word “love” in the former president’s fund-raising notes is an increasingly common tactic for him.
content: The emails have been pleading and plaintive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Investigators Trace Former Police Commissioner’s Ties to Nightclubs
description: Police officers have been asked for communications that would show that rewards were offered for favorable treatment of night spots, said a person familiar with the investigation.
content: Federal investigators are seeking communications among New York’s former police commissioner, his twin brother and officers that might show payments made in exchange for favors to nightclubs, according to a person with direct knowledge of the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Real Trump Mystery
description: How is it possible that the former president has a reasonable chance of winning the election despite all that voters now know about him?
content: The mystery of 2024: How is it possible that Donald Trump has a reasonable chance of winning the presidency despite all that voters now know about him? Why hasn’t a decisive majority risen to deny a second term to a man in line to be judged the worst president in American history?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Isabella Kwai
title: One Person Killed in Bus Hijacking in Los Angeles
description: The bus was taken over by a gunman early Wednesday while several passengers were on board, the police said. A suspect was taken into custody.
content: A gunman hijacked a bus in South Los Angeles early Wednesday and led the police on a low-speed chase that ended an hour later in the city’s downtown, with one passenger killed, a suspect in custody and the bus driver being lauded as a hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Casts Herself as a Pro-Business Pragmatist in a Broad Economic Pitch
description: Declaring “I am a capitalist” in a speech in Pittsburgh, Kamala Harris promised not to be “constrained by ideology” even as she said she would fiercely defend unions and the middle class.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris laid out a broad vision of her economic plan on Wednesday as she sought to bridge the political divide between the progressive senator who ran for president in 2019 and the pragmatic, pro-business candidate she is presenting herself as now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Tripp Mickle
title: Behind OpenAI’s Audacious Plan to Make A.I. Flow Like Electricity
description: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, is talking to the United Arab Emirates, Asian chipmakers and U.S. officials to expand the computing power needed to build artificial intelligence.
content: Late last year, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, started pitching an audacious plan that he hoped would create the computing power his company needed to build more powerful artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Harris’s Economic Pitch: Capitalism for the Middle Class
description: In a major address in Pittsburgh, the vice president praised business and used technical language to court economy-minded voters skeptical of big government.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris wants voters to know that she is not a socialist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Executives Exit as C.E.O. Works to Make the Company For-Profit
description: Mira Murati, the chief technology officer, and two others are leaving as leaders including Sam Altman work to transform the start-up.
content: Mira Murati, the chief technology officer at OpenAI, the influential artificial intelligence start-up, said on Wednesday that she would leave the company after working there for more than six years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Allied Countries Accuse Taliban of ‘Gross’ Violations of Women’s Rights
description: Germany, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands said they will take the Taliban to the U.N.’s highest court because of its harsh restrictions on Afghan women.
content: Four countries on Wednesday accused the Taliban of “gross and systematic” violations of the U.N. treaty on women’s rights in Afghanistan, saying they would take the group to the world’s highest court because of its harsh, widely criticized restrictions on women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Thursday Briefing: The U.S. Pushes for a Cease-Fire in Lebanon
description: Plus, 3,600-year-old cheese.
content: The U.S. is working to broker a short-term cease-fire to halt the violence between Israel and Hezbollah, an American official said yesterday, in the hope of averting a wider war in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mark Robinson’s Top Staff in the Lieutenant Governor’s Office Plan to Resign
description: North Carolina’s Republican nominee for governor has already lost most of his campaign staff after a news report linked him to disturbing comments on a porn site.
content: Senior staff members in the office of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina have said they will resign on Oct. 1, becoming the latest people to abandon Mr. Robinson, the state’s Republican nominee for governor,  in the wake of a CNN report that linked him to disturbing comments on a porn site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Desi Lydic: Donald Trump ‘Really Knows How to Flatter a Lady’
description: The “Daily Show” host said the former president had been so unpopular with women that he was now trying to turn on “the old Trump charm.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Police Arrest Man Who Threw Explosive Device in California Courthouse
description: The police said the man tried to escape after the explosion. He is being held without bail, the authorities said.
content: A man wearing body armor detonated an explosive device inside a courthouse in Santa Maria, Calif., on Wednesday, injuring multiple people before he was arrested, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Brandeis President Steps Down Amid Budget Issues and Protests
description: The university has seen major drops in enrollment, even as the president invited students concerned about protests and antisemitism on other campuses to transfer.
content: Brandeis University said on Wednesday that its president of eight years, Ronald D. Liebowitz, will step down. The announcement by the university’s board of trustees followed a vote of no confidence in Dr. Liebowitz by the faculty, which accused him of “damaging errors in judgment and poor leadership.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wilson
title: A Next Generation Approach to Heating and Cooling Buildings
description: A fifth-generation network at the Bankside Yards project in London offers new possibilities for the pace of decarbonization in the United Kingdom and elsewhere.
content: Tourists strolling along the banks of the River Thames in the heart of London will soon have reason to be grateful for a busy construction site on their path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Mattathias Schwartz and Zachary Small
title: His Father Is Leaving Office. Is Hunter Biden’s Art Market Also Over?
description: Some see hope and skill reflected in the Biden paintings. Critics say their success, and significant prices, were boosted by Joe Biden’s celebrity and stature.
content: After an ambitious New York gallery announced in 2021 that it would sell Hunter Biden’s paintings for as much as $500,000, some ethics experts and House Republicans expressed concern that such high-priced works from a novice artist could become a conduit for those seeking to influence his father, the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Janice Hallett Spins Murder Mysteries Out of Emails, Memos and Texts
description: After years of this-and-that jobs, Hallett began to write a novel: “What do I have to lose?” Now a widely celebrated voice in crime fiction, she just launched her fifth book, “The Examiner.”
content: Janice Hallett never imagined that, in her 50s, she would become a novelist, let alone a celebrated new voice in crime fiction. But a few years ago, after a lifetime of other jobs — beauty-industry journalist, government speechwriter-for-hire, frustrated author of unproduced screenplays — she fired up her laptop and opened a blank document.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Trump Golf Course Suspect Is Charged With Attempted Assassination
description: The new federal indictment in Florida comes on top of two gun charges against Ryan W. Routh, an itinerant contractor with an extensive criminal record.
content: The man accused of lurking with a gun near former President Donald J. Trump at one of his Florida golf courses was charged on Tuesday with the attempted assassination of a presidential candidate, a crime that carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Riley-Adams
title: The Man Behind Ferrari’s Fashion Line on What Fuels His Designs
description: Rocco Iannone is inspired by Joshua Tree, his middle school teacher and cats.
content: A few months ago, I brought the Ferrari creative team to Lago di Monate (1) outside of Milan to brainstorm the next fashion show. But we weren’t just putting together mood boards; we were sharing personal stories. My father, Giuseppe, who owned a cereal producing company, taught me the importance of giving and receiving love. This picture of us from my childhood (2), taken in 1986, captures a spontaneous moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Making Tender Scones at Home Is Easier Than You Think
description: All you need is a bowl, fork and baking sheet for fresh, warm scones with crisp tops and soft centers.
content: A few years ago, my kids and I decided that the cost of going out for brunch didn’t make sense. I could easily and quickly make cheesy scrambled eggs, bacon and breakfast potatoes at home for far less money, and we wouldn’t have to wait in line, squeeze into a too-small table or shout to be heard. It became something of a weekly ritual, and the one thing they always asked for is homemade scones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Four Swing States That Could Matter Most
description: In a tight election, every battleground matters. But here are four states to watch extra closely.
content: The 2024 presidential election is, according to where the polls stand right now, confoundingly close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Ian C. Bates
title: Silicon Valley Renegades Pollute the Sky to Save the Planet
description: Some restless entrepreneurs are releasing pollutants in the sky to try to cool the planet.
content: SARATOGA, Calif. — A silver Winnebago pulled up to a self storage warehouse on the outskirts of a Silicon Valley suburb and three renegade climate entrepreneurs piled out, all mohawks, mustaches and camouflage shorts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Valerie Crowder
title: 30 Miles Inland, Tallahassee Is Bracing for Hurricane-Force Winds From Helene
description: “I’m praying for the best,” one resident said, “but I’m expecting the worst.”
content: Tallahassee, Florida’s capital, is at least 30 miles inland from the Gulf of Mexico. The National Weather Service has no record of the city ever sustaining hurricane-force winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Edward Wong and Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. and Allies Propose Cease-Fire Between Israel and Hezbollah
description: With fears growing of a wider regional war in the Middle East, the United States, European allies and Arab nations were working to broker a 21-day pause in the fighting.
content: The United States, its allies in Europe and several Arab nations on Wednesday unveiled a joint cease-fire proposal to temporarily end the recent deadly fighting between Israel and Hezbollah, hoping to avert a wider war and bolster stalled negotiations between Israel and Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones’s Infowars Will Be Auctioned Off to Pay Sandy Hook Families
description: A sale of the Infowars website and other property is set for November, and could determine the conspiracy theorist’s fate as a broadcaster.
content: A Houston bankruptcy judge ruled on Tuesday that assets from the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones’s Infowars empire can be auctioned off to help pay families of the Sandy Hook mass shooting victims the defamation awards he owes them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
description: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
content: World leaders gathered in New York to hear President Biden and other speakers address the 79th meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. Calls to end the Middle East conflict and wars in Ukraine and Sudan were expected to dominate the weeklong conference, all goals that still look out of reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: This Black Hole Has a Cosmic Wingspan
description: Astronomers have discovered a black hole emitting energy in jets longer than the width of 140 Milky Way galaxies.
content: Who knew a dragon’s tongue could be so long?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Kamala Harris Is a Woman of Faith. She Shouldn’t Be Afraid to Show It.
description: Democrats should fight for religious voters.
content: After Joe Biden called Vice President Kamala Harris to tell her that he was dropping out of the race for president, “one of the first calls Harris made was to her longtime pastor,” The Rev. Amos C. Brown of San Francisco’s Third Baptist Church, Mississippi Today reported in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: They Were Promised a Charming ‘Bridgerton’ Ball. They Got a Pole Dance.
description: A Detroit event evoked memories of Glasgow’s Willy Wonka debacle. We look at how they stack up against each other.
content: It was a terrible event that was poorly planned, way too expensive and ultimately a big downer, attendees said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry of F.D.A. Device Chief’s Potential Conflicts
description: A top medical device regulator’s work overlapped at times with his wife’s legal representation of clients with business before the agency.
content: Two members of Congress have asked an inspector general to investigate whether the top federal regulator for medical devices like pacemakers and artificial hips acted ethically in work that overlapped with that of his wife, a leading lawyer for device companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Report Links Mark Robinson to Comment That Cops Should Have ‘Shot Al Sharpton’
description: The newly unearthed remarks were made in the comments of a news article under a username that previous reporting has linked to Mr. Robinson, the Republican running for governor in North Carolina.
content: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina, the embattled Republican running for governor there, appeared to suggest in an online comment in 2009 that police officers should have shot the Rev. Al Sharpton, according to a report published on Wednesday by the conservative news site The Bulwark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Cat Glover, Who Danced With Prince, Dies at 62
description: She worked with Prince on many of his signature works, including the “Sign o’ the Times” tour and the “U Got the Look” music video.
content: Cat Glover, a dancer and choreographer for Prince who added a frenetic flair to the artist’s late 1980s ensembles, and who danced onstage with him during his “Sign o’ the Times” tour, has died at her home in Los Angeles. She was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast: A Word With John Summit
description: The dance music superstar and former accountant speaks on the return of EDM and his rise, from underground parties to headlining Madison Square Garden.
content: The dance music superstar John Summit has become one of the scene’s biggest forces in recent years with a big-tent approach to house music that bridges aficionados and weekend warriors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Ben Hubbard, Diana Nguyen, Will Reid, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Slide Toward War in Lebanon
description: Israel, aiming to weaken the militant group Hezbollah, has pounded the country with deadly airstrikes, including densely populated parts of Beirut.
content: In the past few days, Israel has waged intense air raids in Lebanon, killing more than 600 people, according to the Lebanese Health Ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Canadians Fell Out of Love With Justin Trudeau
description: Canada’s Liberals are reeling from a string of setbacks, even as the party survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday.
content: Canadian politics are getting fiery.

title: Myha’la’s Relationship Advice? Get in a Fight.
description: The “Industry” star on how she learned to have a healthy argument with her new fiancé.
content: On the HBO high finance drama “Industry,” basically everyone serves cruel insults. It’s part of the culture at their bank, Pierpoint. But Myha’la’s character, Harper Stern, goes after friends and enemies with deep, cutting verbal attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Naftali Herstik, Soulful and Influential Cantor, Dies at 77
description: Part of a long line of cantors, he led services at the Great Synagogue in Jerusalem for 30 years and helped train the next generation.
content: Naftali Herstik, whose soulful, resonant tenor and elegant interpretations of Jewish liturgical music made him one of the most renowned and influential cantors of his time, died on Sept. 1 at his home in Ra’anana, Israel. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan and U.S. Work to Counter China’s Drone Dominance
description: Officials hope that Taiwan can become a bigger player in the supply chain for drones, a move that would also help blunt any threats posed to the island by China.
content: Spurred by worries about China’s strength in mass-producing drones, American and Taiwanese companies and government officials are working to join forces in making the air and sea vehicles that could be crucial to defending Taiwan.

title: A School for the Basketball World
description: The Earl Monroe New Renaissance Basketball School, a charter high school in the Bronx, offers basketball, but wants its students to succeed off the court.

title: Kushner’s Fund Has Reaped Millions in Fees, but So Far Returned No Profits
description: The son-in-law of former President Donald J. Trump has said he has intentionally moved slowly to invest investors’ money, which came primarily from foreign entities.
content: The private equity firm run by Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of former President Donald J. Trump, has been paid at least $112 million in fees since 2021 by Saudi Arabia and other foreign investors, even though as of July it had not yet returned any profits to the governments largely bankrolling the firm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 25, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024.
content: A picture caption with an article on Monday about the Fête de l’Humanité, an annual French Communism celebration, misstated its inaugural year. As the article correctly stated, it was 1930, not 1945. In addition, because of an editing error, the approximate age of the event was misstated in the article. It is almost 100 years old, not almost 80 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Study Finds Climate Change Doubled Likelihood of Recent European Floods
description: Storm Boris dumped record amounts of rain over Central and Eastern Europe this month. A new study found climate change made the deluge more likely.
content: Europe faced catastrophic floodwaters that affected two million people earlier this month and transformed neighborhoods and urban centers into muddy rivers. At least 24 people died, and some were reported missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China Says It Launched a Rocket With a Dummy Warhead Into the Pacific
description: The ballistic missile launch is a sign of the commitment of Xi Jinping, China’s leader, to continue strengthening the country’s Rocket Force and to project power in Asia.
content: China launched an intercontinental ballistic missile carrying a dummy warhead that landed in the Pacific Ocean on Wednesday, the country’s defense ministry announced, in a sign of President Xi Jinping’s commitment to keep strengthening China’s missile force after a period of corruption scandals and command turbulence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
title: Hezbollah Targets Tel Aviv as Israel Moves Forces Toward Lebanon
description: A top Israeli military official hinted to soldiers of a possible ground invasion as the United States and France drafted a cease-fire proposal to try to stave off a broader conflict.
content: The Lebanese militia Hezbollah on Wednesday fired a missile deep into Israel, targeting Tel Aviv for the first time, as the Israeli military called up two brigades of reserve soldiers and sent them north toward the border with Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Mohn and Matilde Viegas
title: Pontevedra, a Spanish City That Picked Pedestrians Over Cars
description: For over two decades the city’s mayor has reclaimed public space for people and limited vehicles in the city center, which reduced traffic and improved air quality.
content: Pontevedra may be a smaller city in northwest Spain, but it has been a pioneer in favoring pedestrians over cars for more than 20 years. The city has played a large role in inspiring other municipalities and continues to be a model on how to successfully confront the challenges of climate change by reducing traffic and cutting emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: NewJeans’ Ultimatum Casts K-Pop’s Displays of Labor in a New Light
description: The breakout girl group went public with complaints against its parent company, Hybe, which has just released a new TV series and film about the control it exerts over stars.
content: A huge part of the success of NewJeans — the most creatively promising new K-pop act of the past two years — has been its music videos: stylistically sophisticated, vividly colorful, palpably joyful. Starting with music that deploys top-shelf songwriting buoyed by production savvy about global microtrends, the group developed a singular aesthetic to go with it, drawing equally from high fashion, lived-in nostalgia and contemporary cuteness.

description: Despite the danger, older residents, firefighters, medics and a few small-business owners chose to stay put in Kiryat Shmona, the northernmost Israeli city near the border with Lebanon.
content: Puffs of smoke were still rising from a storage center a day after a barrage of rockets fired by Hezbollah pounded Kiryat Shmona, the northernmost Israeli city near the border with Lebanon.

description: Share your thoughts with the On Politics newsletter.
content: It’s autumn! The season of falling leaves, Halloween costumes and — this year — wall-to-wall political advertising.

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Fleeing Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon, and Worrying About Where to Go Next
description: After years of decline, Lebanon is ill-equipped to deal with a wave of displaced people. One family left their farm and found themselves homeless in Beirut.
content: Ahmed Issa and his family spent 20 hours on the road from southern Lebanon, most of it stuck sweating in bumper-to-bumper traffic, before reaching a shelter in Beirut on Tuesday afternoon. Already, he was looking for another place to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: Jack DeJohnette, One of Jazz’s Great Drummers, Has a Surprise
description: At 82, the musician known for his work with Miles Davis and Keith Jarrett will perform a rare solo concert on his first instrument: the piano.
content: In the early 1960s, Jack DeJohnette, a pianist from Chicago, took a weeklong gig at the Showboat club in Philadelphia with the saxophonist Eddie Harris and played his second instrument: the drums. (A bandmate had left a set at his house.) At one point, Harris, an older player whose career was starting to gain steam, took DeJohnette aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hughes
title: Why Do People Like Elon Musk Love Donald Trump? It’s Not Just About Money.
description: Trump’s backers in tech see him as a fellow victim of the state and a shield they need to escape accountability.
content: On a Friday morning in May, a day after Donald Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts in a scheme to influence the 2016 election by falsifying business records, I met a tech leader for breakfast in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. A lifelong Democrat, he had recently reinvented himself as an ardent Trump supporter. Unmoved by the conviction, he was on his way to a fund-raiser for the former president about a week later (starting ticket price: $50,000).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Heads Up: That Patient Portal May Contain Your Therapy Notes
description: Health care systems have been putting therapists’ progress reports online, much to the surprise (and anger) of some patients.

I spent a few days learning more about its efforts and hearing about the situation for Russian officers, soldiers, drafted civilians, conscripts and deserters.

author: By Kevin Williams and Jill Cowan
title: Chemical Leak From Rail Yard Near Cincinnati Prompts Evacuations
description: A train car in Whitewater Township, Ohio, was discovered to be leaking styrene, which is used to make plastic and fiberglass and is highly flammable.

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: This Cheese Stood Alone for 3,600 Years
description: The cheese was dug up with mummified human remains in the Xinjiang region of China and offers insights into the origins of the dairy product known as kefir.
content: Around 3,600 years ago, a young woman died and was buried in the Tarim Basin, a desert in what’s now the Xinjiang region of northwestern China. The dry conditions and her sealed coffin preserved her body, so when archaeologists uncovered her grave in 2003, they found her naturally mummified remains, still dressed in a felt hat, tasseled wool coat and fur-lined leather boots.

author: By J. Hoberman
title: Bresson’s ‘Lancelot du Lac’: The Undoing of Camelot
description: Broken by failure, the knights don their creaking armor and take aim at one another, as a desolate Lancelot tries to sever his bonds with Guinevere.
content: Although he nursed the idea of a knights in armor film as early as the 1950s, Robert Bresson only realized the project in 1974. As singular as one might expect, his “Lancelot du Lac,” unfolds in a medieval world at once clichéd and unfamiliar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Harris Cast Herself as a Pro-Business Pragmatist
description: Also, the U.S. is trying to broker an Israel-Hezbollah cease-fire. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: In a closely watched speech on economic policy this afternoon in Pittsburgh, Kamala Harris promised “a new way forward” for the middle class, and portrayed Donald Trump as on the side of billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Bernie Moreno Under Fire Over Comments About Suburban Women
description: Mr. Moreno, a Republican running for Senate in Ohio, suggested that older women shouldn’t care about abortion because they were too old to have children, comments Nikki Haley pointedly criticized.
content: Bernie Moreno, the Republican Senate candidate in Ohio, is facing criticism over demeaning remarks he made last week about women who support abortion rights, including from Nikki Haley, the former Republican presidential candidate and one of the most prominent women in her party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump’s Low-Tax, High-Tariff Strategy Could Clash With Economic Realities
description: The former president’s efforts to compel companies to remain in the United States had limited success while he was in the White House.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump makes his closing economic argument ahead of the election, he is outlining a vision for a manufacturing renaissance that reprises a familiar pitch: Make goods in America and enjoy low taxes, or face punishing tariffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Judge Demands a Plan for a Possible Federal Takeover of Rikers
description: Judge Laura Taylor Swain said a “carousel” of jail leaders had failed to stop violence. She ordered lawyers for the city and prisoners to show her what a receivership might look like.
content: A federal judge overseeing New York City’s violent and dangerous jails on Wednesday ordered Department of Correction leaders to meet with lawyers for prisoners to create a plan for an “outside person” who could run the system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Exploring the Roots of Mideast Turbulence Onstage
description: A retrospective in Paris honors Lina Majdalanie and Rabih Mroué, whose theater works have examined the region’s troubles for decades.
content: The theater-makers Lina Majdalanie and Rabih Mroué have grown accustomed to life in exile. In 2013, the duo, who are creative as well as life partners, left their home country of Lebanon to settle in Berlin — out of “fatigue,” Majdalanie said recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Theodore Schleifer
title: Inside Harris’s Big Economic Pitch
description: The vice president is expected to deliver one of her most detailed addresses yet on the issue, as she seeks to strike a delicate political balance.
content: Kamala Harris on Wednesday is expected to deliver a detailed economic address in which she will seek to define herself as a defender of the middle class, entrepreneurs and consumers who will also take on bad actors in the business world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yussef Cole
title: Echoes of Wisdom Empowers Zelda to Create Her Own Path
description: Princess Zelda’s magic wand can make a copy of nearly everything in the game, offering inventive solutions to enemy encounters and environmental puzzles.
content: The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom finds us once again in the imperiled medieval fantasy world of Hyrule. This time, a mysterious force has been creating disastrous rifts that suck buildings and people alike into a dark and mysterious void. You start by fighting through a dungeon as Link, the protagonist of every previous Legend of Zelda game, but your time with him is brief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: France Prepares to Raise Taxes on Businesses and the Rich
description: France’s new prime minister, Michel Barnier, has opened the door to reversing some of President Emmanuel Macron’s tax cuts in an effort to fix the country’s widening budget deficit.
content: In the seven years that he has been France’s president, Emmanuel Macron has bet on tax cuts for the wealthy and for corporations as a recipe for stimulating the economy. His new government is about to tear up that playbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Confronting Our New Reality
description: Solutions to the problem of climate change have never been more clear. But the scale of the problem keeps getting bigger.
content: For a hot minute, it looked like the Doomers might be proved wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis and Mikael Olsson
title: It Was Their Dream Home. But Could They Grapple With Its Dark Legacy?
description: After a Berlin couple discovered who’d once lived there, they still wanted to make the house their own.
content: IN SEPTEMBER 2018, the fashion designer Maria Koch sent her husband, the magazine editor Joerg Koch, the real estate listing for a two-story, Alpine-style house at the eastern edge of Berlin’s Grunewald forest. From the street, it resembled something out of a Bavarian fairy tale: exposed wooden beams, decorative wrought-iron window grids and a white stucco facade with a gabled roof. Compared to the other houses in the wealthy neighborhood of Schmargendorf — “white palazzos, really tacky stuff,” says Joerg — this one stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, Elyssa Dudley, Wendy Dorr, Sophia Lanman, Alissa Wilkinson, Jason Zinoman and Margaret Lyons
title: In Defense of Hate-Watching
description: In a world of infinite media, why do we watch bad TV?
content: With a multitude of channels and streaming platforms, there are more movies and television series available to watch than ever. And yet, many viewers decide to spend their precious time plopped in front of a bad show, season after season, just to pick it apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Abigail Geiger, Rachel Nostrant and Elisabeth Parker
title: In Florida’s Big Bend, Preparing Wearily for the Third Hurricane in 13 Months
description: Hurricane Helene is forecast to be much larger and stronger than other recent storms, with up to 18 feet of storm surge expected along the marshy coastline south of Tallahassee.
content: The immense task of preparing for Hurricane Helene, a storm so large that no part of Florida may be untouched by wind, rain or storm surge, fell disproportionately on Wednesday to the frustrated people of the Gulf Coast, whose memories of recent storms remain vivid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: How Caribbean Pepper Sauce Gets Its Fire
description: Across the region and the diaspora, the Scotch bonnet lends its distinctive, tart, numbing heat to this hot sauce, offering a taste of the islands and a punch of flavor.
content: As a child, the cookbook author Lesley Enston learned maybe the most important lesson about pepper sauce from her uncle Richard in Trinidad and Tobago: Be very careful when handling Scotch bonnet chiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden, on ‘The View,’ Calls Trump a ‘Loser’ Who Lacks ‘Redeeming Value’
description: President Biden became the first sitting president to appear live on “The View.” He said he was “at peace” with his decision not to run again.
content: President Biden on Wednesday delivered a blunt assessment of the character of his predecessor, telling the hosts of “The View” on ABC that “there’s not a lot of socially redeeming value” to former President Donald J. Trump. Asked if he would have won if he stayed in the presidential race, Mr. Biden replied: “Yes. I was confident I would beat Trump. He’s a loser.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Conveying Confidence Through Clothing
description: Signs of self-assurance were apparent in outfits on and off the runways at Milan Fashion Week.
content: The style on and off the runways at Milan Fashion Week has a self-assurance that can be particularly noticeable to those arriving straight from London Fashion Week, which turned 40 this year but has maintained a fledgling spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Leadership Failures Helped Lead to FAFSA Debacle, Watchdog Finds
description: Two reports by the Government Accountability Office found that mismanagement and wildly unrealistic projections derailed the student aid application process this year.
content: Leaders in the Education Department systematically failed to manage deadlines and badly underestimated technical shortcomings while overhauling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, according to a pair of damaging reports released by the Government Accountability Office on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Elaine Harrison
title: Both My Abortions Were Necessary. Only One Gets Sympathy.
description: There are many reasons to terminate a pregnancy.
content: Here are two abortion stories. Both are mine. Both came with heartache and upheaval — and both prevented heartache and upheaval. One was an experience common to many abortion patients, but one that people often look on with disdain. The other was the sort that generally garners public sympathy. I wish they both did.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s today’s schedule.
description: Below is a schedule for the Climate Forward event. Note that times are subject to change.
content: Below is a schedule for the Climate Forward event. Note that times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Hurricane John Batters Mexico’s Coast for the Second Time This Week
description: The storm, which hit southwestern Mexico as a Category 3 hurricane this week, is again threatening parts of the country’s Pacific Coast, this time as a Category 1.
content: Hurricane John ravaged Mexico’s Guerrero State earlier this week before weakening into a tropical storm, but it is once again threatening the country’s Pacific Coast, which has been drenched by the storm’s rains and battered by its winds in recent days and can expect to receive even more, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Donald Trump Cut Ties to Some Online Fund-Raisers
description: The campaign also reduced the commission retained by the remaining vendors, as the former president falls behind Vice President Kamala Harris in the cash race.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign cut ties late last week with a number of digital firms that had been fund-raising for the campaign and slashed the commission that the remaining vendors can retain by 10 percentage points, according to four people briefed on the changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta Unveils New Smart Glasses and Headsets in Pursuit of the Metaverse
description: At an event in Silicon Valley, the company exhibited a range of products meant to blend the real world and virtual reality, with a healthy dose of A.I.
content: Mark Zuckerberg has spent billions of dollars, hired thousands of employees and worked for roughly a quarter of his life in pursuit of a vision: a future in which the physical and digital worlds are interwoven to connect people around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: How to Use Up an Entire Jar of Sun-Dried Tomatoes
description: Make use of that savory oil with this brilliant pasta recipe.
content: Why, hello there. It’s Eric Kim, filling in for Melissa Clark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: What Is Zelensky’s ‘Victory Plan’ for Ukraine’s War With Russia?
description: The Ukrainian leader aims to present President Biden with a strategy to improve his country’s position ahead of any peace negotiations with Russia.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is visiting the United States this week for the United Nations General Assembly, where he will deliver a speech on Wednesday. Beyond the formal addresses, he has one primary objective: selling what he calls his “victory plan” to Western allies, especially President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: She Found a Home in Music. Now She’s the Composer for the King.
description: Errollyn Wallen, a Belize-born artist who has been named master of music by King Charles, discusses music as an escape, confronting racism and living by the sea.
content: The call from Buckingham Palace came on a summer morning, when Errollyn Wallen, wearing a pink onesie with pom-pom trim, had just finished a breakfast of toast and marmalade at her seaside home in Scotland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Nation’s Politics Are Dramatic. Now Its Dramas Are Political.
description: For the second year in a row, a play about the Constitution is the most-staged in America. And a farce about a terrible president is also pretty popular.
content: The United States is in the final stages of a dramatic election year, with an unexpected change of candidates, two assassination attempts, and a remarkably close contest. Now it turns out that many of the nation’s theaters are leaning into the politics of the moment, programming shows that explore, or mock, the state of affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,195
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 26, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanis Elsborg
title: The N.B.A. Is Partnering With a Repressive Regime
description: How can the N.B.A. square its profession of high ideals with doing business with a repressive government?
content: In a bygone era, N.B.A. teams enforced an unofficial quota on Black players, apparently fearing that a “too Black” team might alienate its white audience. Today, this same league is celebrated as one of the world’s most progressive sports organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: A File Cabinet Yields a Rare Copy of the U.S. Constitution
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 25, 2024
content: “Part of what is so powerful about it is that it’s just this thin piece of paper. It’s a simple thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is This What Female Strength Looks Like?
description: Saint Laurent and Dior struggle with the answer.
content: First the pussy bow, and now the tie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: When Computers Go Dark
description: A routine software update by a security company crashed millions of computers around the world. The chaos was telling.
content: Two months ago, what should have been a routine software update by a security company, CrowdStrike, crashed millions of computers around the world running Microsoft Windows. Airlines grounded flights. Subways stopped. Operators of 911 lines couldn’t dispatch help. Stores shut down. Hospitals canceled surgeries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: What’s Eating Trump? The Singing ‘Ghost of John McCain’
description: The former senator haunts the former president, or vice versa, in this sophomoric musical satire.
content: Usually, critics wait until a show is running to slam it, but Meghan McCain broke the embargo. By more than five months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: With Stickers on Phone Cameras, Clubs Defend the Party Vibe
description: It’s standard practice in Berlin, and camera covering is catching on in London, Ibiza and New York as clubs seek to protect an anything-goes atmosphere.
content: On a recent Sunday afternoon, the line outside Berghain, the Berlin techno club, stretched for hours. Hundreds of visitors, sweating in black outfits, lined the dusty path to the door, hoping to be allowed into the former power station, which is known worldwide for its tough door policy, starry D.J. lineups and hedonistic parties lasting nearly 36 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Kentucky Sheriff Accused of Fatally Shooting Judge Pleads Not Guilty
description: Sheriff Shawn Stines made his first appearance in court as a defendant in the case that has shaken the small rural community of Letcher County, Ky.
content: A Kentucky sheriff charged with first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of a judge pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a case that has shaken the small rural community of Letcher County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: In Switzerland, Reported Use of Suicide Capsule Inflames Debate
description: The Swiss police said they had detained “several individuals” after a 64-year-old American woman reportedly died by suicide using the controversial device.
content: The authorities in northern Switzerland said they were investigating a reported assisted suicide using a controversial device that replaces oxygen with lethal nitrogen gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Make Typing Easier on the Phone and Leave the Laptop at Home
description: Shortcuts, small external keyboards and even improved (and free) dictation software can make long sessions of text input much simpler.
content: With summer officially over, it’s back to business (or school) for many people, which can mean more time writing longer things, especially on the go. The smartphone has replaced the laptop for many tasks, but when it comes to text input, tapping away on tiny onscreen keys might make you wish you had hauled along the computer just for its keyboard. Thankfully, your phone includes several features to make text entry much easier. Here are a few suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Congress Passes Short-Term Spending Bill to Avert a Shutdown
description: In a pair of votes in quick succession, the House and Senate moved to keep federal funding flowing through Dec. 20. But they punted a bigger spending fight to the end of the year.
content: Congress on Wednesday gave final approval to a short-term spending bill to avert a government shutdown just ahead of the November elections, sending the legislation to President Biden’s desk but punting a bigger funding fight to the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Ocasio-Cortez Says Adams Should Resign ‘for the Good of the City’
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez became the most prominent elected official to call for Mayor Eric Adams to no longer lead New York City.
content: Follow live updates on Mayor Eric Adams’s indictment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong and Ye Fan
title: At Book Release Parties, Fans Go Loony for Rooney
description: Sally Rooney lovers reveled, played trivia and took part in raffles to celebrate the Irish novelist’s new book, “Intermezzo.”
content: It was close to midnight, and dozens of people — a few of whom, clad in club wear, came straight from a Charli XCX and Troye Sivan concert — had gathered at Greenlight Bookstore in Brooklyn. As the hour approached, the crowd began to count down: “… nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one!” Cheers, flashes abounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Zelensky Warns U.N. Against Conceding to Russia’s ‘Insane’ Desire for Land
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told the meeting of world leaders that capitulating to Russia would only give its president, Vladimir Putin, the “political space to continue the war.”
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the United Nations on Wednesday to prevent Russia from freezing the war as it is now, saying that the Kremlin “still wants even more land — more land, which is insane, and is seizing it day by day while wanting to destroy its neighbor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
title: A Litmus Test in Japan: Should Spouses Be Able to Have Different Surnames?
description: The nine candidates vying to become prime minister have been differentiated by their stances on a law requiring married couples to share a family name.
content: Japan’s leaders have plenty to think about. The country’s population is shrinking and rapidly aging. One neighbor, North Korea, is a nuclear menace, while another, China, is escalating territorial incursions and information warfare. On top of that: climate change, ballooning national debt, inflation and a slowing economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger, Nicholas Nehamas and Theodore Schleifer
title: Meet the G.O.P. Personal Injury Lawyer Buying His Own Trump Ads
description: Dan Newlin has spent millions on billboards and TV spots promoting Donald J. Trump (and himself).
content: Late last week, a series of TV ads began running in Pennsylvania blasting Kamala Harris’s record on law enforcement and immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 473
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Sept. 26, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: A Remote Alaskan Island Is on High Alert for a Rat
description: Wildlife experts fear that a rat could disrupt the island’s delicate balance, so they are pulling out all the stops.
content: The last time a rat found its way to Alaska’s St. Paul Island, in 2018, residents took nearly a year to find and kill it. Officials fear another rat has arrived, and they have enlisted residents and the federal government on a fevered hunt to catch it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Troy Closson
title: What to Know About New York City’s New Schools Chancellor
description: Melissa Aviles-Ramos, a former English teacher and deputy chancellor, will assume the post after David C. Banks steps down in December.
content: Melissa Aviles-Ramos, who will take over in January as the next chancellor of New York City’s public school system, is a longtime New York educator who oversaw the schools’ response to the arrival of tens of thousands of migrant children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: To Win in North Carolina, Democrats Need to Get Out of Town
description: Harris has a chance in the state, but only if she hits the ground hard in rural areas, as Obama did in 2008.
content: Many miles east of Charlotte, on North Carolina’s Highway 64, churches beckon drivers with offers of deliverance. “Are you sure you’re saved?” one sign says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Want to Turn Your House into the Art House? Try Metrograph at Home.
description: The Metrograph theater in New York has expanded to include a streaming platform that spotlights foreign, art house, independent, classic and documentary selections.
content: When the Metrograph theater opened on New York’s Lower East Side in spring of 2016, it wasn’t just a cinema; it was an experience, offering up two screens of new independent films, archival screenings and special events, as well as an on-site bar, restaurant and bookshop. In the years that followed, Metrograph’s reach continued to grow, as did the opportunities for film lovers to patronize the theater beyond its walls, thanks to the establishment of Metrograph Pictures (a distribution company restoring and championing archival releases) and the Metrograph Journal (featuring thoughtful film writing from a variety of contributors).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Why Everything Is Suddenly Spiraling for Israel
description: Israel faces a dire threat from the outside, and its prime minister and his allies have been prioritizing their own interests.
content: What would you do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Is Briefed on Iranian Assassination Threats
description: U.S. intelligence agencies had previously tracked a potential Iranian assassination plot. The Trump campaign said in a statement that the threat is now heightened.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump was briefed on Tuesday by U.S. intelligence officials about “specific threats from Iran to assassinate him,” according to his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Samuelsson
title: I’m a Chef. This Grain Should Be the Next Quinoa.
description: As climate change threatens the availability of food, we must diversify what’s on our plates.
content: In 1999, Ruth Reichl, then the editor in chief of Gourmet, asked me if I would travel around Ethiopia, the country of my birth, with a writer for the magazine. I hadn’t been back since my Swedish parents adopted me when I was about 2 years old, and when the plane touched down there, I was overcome with emotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: France’s Horrifying Rape Trial Has a Feminist Hero
description: Gisèle Pelicot waived anonymity to make public the trial of her former husband and the 50 men accused of joining him in raping her. Her poise and courage have made her an icon.
content: Each morning, when Gisèle Pelicot arrives at the courthouse, dozens of supporters, mainly women, are already there, waiting for her. When she leaves each night, they line her path to applaud and cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What We Know About Hezbollah’s Military Capability
description: The Iran-backed militants have perhaps the largest arsenal of any armed group in the world, excluding governments, experts say.
content: Israel’s recent assault on Hezbollah has dealt a blow to the Lebanese militant group, but how big a blow is unclear. This is partly because Hezbollah, like most armed groups, has shrouded its precise military capacity in secrecy. Hezbollah is supported by Iran, which sees it as its most important proxy in the region, and for decades, Tehran has funneled weapons and other military technology to the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How the Artist Liza Lou ‘Messes With Your Mind’
description: Her medium is the tiny seed bead. Her canvas ranges from a 35-foot-long mobile home to the chauvinist history of Abstract Expressionism.
content: A gun, a bottle of Jack Daniels, a splatter, a million beads. With these details, the California artist Liza Lou tells you stories. And just a minuscule bead, she explains, is like an underlined word: it can focus your attention, and slow you down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Ages and Theodore Tae
title: A 25-Minute Strength Workout for Beginners
description: New to the weight room? This routine is for you.
content: If you’re new to lifting, navigating the weight room can feel like a bigger challenge than the workout itself. But it’s worth overcoming that initial intimidation; a regular strength training regimen can positively impact mental health, improve longevity and make it easier to accomplish daily tasks. That’s even more important as you age, when loss of muscle strength can put you at greater risk of falling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Parents Are Cash-Strapped. Why Won’t They Sell Some of Their Land?
description: Unable to treat her parents as often as she would like, a reader is unsure how to encourage them to take a big step toward financial self-reliance.
content: Growing up, my family’s financial situation was rough, but my siblings and I have done well as adults. Our parents scrape by. My sister once gave them several thousand dollars to pay bills, and I try to be generous with meals, groceries and vacations. I feel guilty about not planning another vacation with them — which they would love — because of my work and family commitments. I have a child with special needs, and when I indulge in luxuries, I feel as if I’m compromising my child’s future. The issue: I just discovered that my parents own some valuable land. They could sell it and finance a comfortable life for themselves, but they want to hang onto it and leave it to us. I would rather they spend their own money — not ours — and leave us nothing. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Colgan
title: Taking on Food Emissions at Their Origin and Consumption
description: Andy Jarvis, Bruce Friedrich, Will Harris and Katie Cantrell are part of a group focused on food who are leading conversations at the Times’s Climate Forward Changemaker Lunch.
content: You might think it strange that the food system, which is responsible for a third of global emissions, is not brought up more as a focus of climate action. You don’t see it in protest slogans, you don’t hear politicians railing about it, and it’s not often a leading subject at climate change gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Shaila Dewan
title: As School Threats Proliferate, More Than 700 Students Are Arrested
description: The number of threats after a Georgia school shooting this month is much higher than usual, many officials said. In response, some have cracked down with arrests and detention for children as young as 10.
content: Earlier this month, a detective knocked on Shavon Harvey’s door, in suburban Ohio, to ask about her son. The son had sent a Snapchat message from her phone to his friends, saying there would be shootings at several schools nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Ages
title: A Beginner’s Guide to the Weight Room
description: Lifting at your local gym can be intimidating. Here’s how to get started.
content: The first time I approached the weight room at my local gym, over a decade ago, I froze with fear in the doorway. The maze of complicated-looking equipment — and the crowd of people who already knew what they were doing — were immediately intimidating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: News Outlets Brace for Chaos on Election Night (and Perhaps Beyond)
description: Here’s how they’re preparing to make calls in a very tight race — and ensure that viewers and readers believe them.
content: The data nerd of NBC News, Steve Kornacki, is preparing to sleep at his desk in 30 Rockefeller Plaza — for days on end, if need be. CNN is adding to its bench of legal experts in case of disputed counts in swing states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What’s Your Reaction to Instagram’s Changes to Improve the Safety and the Health of Teen Users?
description: The app introduced new settings and features aimed at creating more age-appropriate experiences for minors. Do the changes go far enough?
content: Concerns about the effects of social media on adolescents and public demands for better safeguards have been growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Favorite Restaurants
description: What is the best place to eat where you live?
content: The New York Times recently announced its list of the 50 best restaurants in America right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Lebanon’s Growing Civilian Death Toll Includes Children and Rescue Workers
description: Lebanese organizations have begun to identify children, humanitarians and journalists among a growing number of civilians killed in Israel’s intense bombardment.
content: From girl scouts to first aid responders, cleaners to electrical engineers, the names and faces of the Lebanese civilians killed by Israeli airstrikes this week have begun to emerge, as the nation reels from the deadliest day in its history since the 15-year civil war, which ended in 1990.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Brio
description: Peter Gordon’s puzzle comes with surround sound.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Tugend
title: What if Everyone Did Something to Slow Climate Change?
description: Researchers are looking at the impact that individuals’ actions can have on reducing carbon emissions — and the best ways to get people to adopt them.
content: Make more beef-free meals. Compost food scraps. Replace a natural gas stove with an electric one.

author: By Coral Davenport

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Had a Second Chance’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: She twirls the rings on my fingers as we snuggle in bed. Newly 4 and full of questions, my daughter seeks to know the world. “Mommy, why do you wear these rings?” We move effortlessly through her birthstone, my engagement and wedding rings. But how to explain the other three gold bands? Each is a marker of a pregnancy lost, embryos that didn’t grow. These are the siblings I dreamed for you, the babies I longed to hold. Someday we’ll grapple with loss, but today, I share a simple truth: These rings, my darling girl, they are all about love. — Christine Elizabeth Chernikoff

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Simple Stories About the Opioid Epidemic Are Wrong
description: Overdose deaths are finally coming down. Why?
content: Finally, mercifully, the country’s astronomical drug overdose rate appears to be flattening out — even declining. This spring, national data began to show that overdose death rates were, after more than three decades of very steady increases, no longer growing. In fact, they were beginning to drop. By now that fall is clear and striking — suggesting perhaps 10 percent fewer Americans dying from overdoses this year than last, according to a report published last week by NPR. Some leading researchers believe the data is trailing the story, and the decline is even bigger than the backward-looking indicators suggest — perhaps 15 percent year over year.
